reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is almost the same reading you learned with the kanji. Remember たつ? Well this is read たち. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

If you want to pluralize something, <reading>touch</reading> (たち) it to something else. One friend touches another friend, well now they're friends. Plural friends! All thanks to the good ol' pluralizing suffix touch!

Oh, and don't type the 〜 out when writing the answer. It's just there to let you know that there's usually something attached in front of this word.
The reading is like that of 守る, so if you know the reading of that word you should be able to read this one as well.
The reading is the same 笑う or 笑い. It's also the same as what you learned with the kanji.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. いち gets shortened to いっ though, so watch out for that if you want to remain <vocabulary>the best</vocabulary>, yeah?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words 下 and 書く separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading. Just don't forget the rendaku here!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your <reading>ca</reading>r (か)? Please?

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read with either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. This uses a less common kun'yomi of 家, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you live in a <vocabulary>rented house</vocabulary>, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. And when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a <reading>shack</reading>, <reading>yah</reading> (しゃくや) house renter! Enjoy!"

By the way, in the secondary reading しゃっか, the しゃく changes to しゃっ. This reading is mostly used in legal contexts though, so しゃくや is more common.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The しゃく gets shortened to しゃっ though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Similarly to 初耳, 初 behaves more like a prefix here, which means that this uses kun'yomi readings. You already know these for both 初 and 恋, so you should be good to go!

The readings for both of these are readings you haven't learned yet, though maybe you already know this word since it's fairly common. Think of it this way. You have your friend <reading>Tom</reading> (とも) Cruise. You like him, and he likes you. You're close enough friends that you can <reading>touch</reading> (だち) each other too. Like, on the shoulder or on the hand or whatever, without it being awkward. So, you like to <reading>Tom touch</reading> (ともだち) when you can, because he has nice skin.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you're going <vocabulary>to strike</vocabulary> something over and over it makes a <reading>ta-ta</reading> (たた) sound. Imagine you're about <vocabulary>to beat</vocabulary> a steel drum, for example. Now listen... たた! There! Did you hear it?

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

They used to make you <vocabulary>kowtow</vocabulary> every single time you came to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. That's full on head to floor kowtowing in front of everyone who is already in とうきょう to prove that you appreciate being there. They might even make you do it these days too, if you're not being respectful enough while you're there.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading for this word is screwed up, though if we're lucky, you already know the word for cute. It seems to have injected itself into American and English culture a decent amount, anyways. If you are one of the lucky ones, you'll know that this word is read as かわいい. If you're not, think of the cute thing being a cow. Then you say, "that <reading>cowはいい</reading>" (かわいい), or "that cow is good" because it's so cute.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'd like <vocabulary>to announce</vocabulary>... we're not having one baby, we're having <reading>two</reading> (つ) babies!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own, but don't be fooled into using the on'yomis! This isn't ひんぶつ — no, it's しなもの!

Since this word is made up of a single kanji (and is a body part) it uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Remember the mnemonic from when you first learned this kanji? Well こういち is still in your <kanji>throat</kanji> and he doesn't want to get out. In fact, every time you tug on him, he shouts, "<reading>No Do</reading>- (のど)" but you gag and can't hear the rest. People around you think you're saying "No Do-" but it's really just the weirdo living in your throat now. What a pain...

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you really want to get a <vocabulary>larynx</vocabulary> work out, go to <reading>とう</reading>きょう. It's loud, it's crowded, and you have to yell the entire time to get people to hear what you have to say. You also know 18 levels of kanji and you really want to shout them all out, which makes your <vocabulary>voice box</vocabulary> tired (but makes you happy).
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The readings are what you'd expect except for きつ getting shortened to きっ and 茶, which has this strange さ reading. To remember that it's さ instead of ちゃ, think of this <vocabulary>tea house</vocabulary> you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a <reading>saw</reading> (さ) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. Combine 夕 and 焼け (you learned the reading via the kanji) and you'll have <reading>ゆうやけ</reading>.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

If you know how to read 大阪 you can just add 弁 to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.

The readings for this word are all kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 守 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you finish singing a <vocabulary>lullaby</vocabulary> to your child they always ask for <reading>more</reading> (もり). It doesn't matter how many you sing, they always want at least one more before they will fall asleep.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If your life is filled with nothing but <vocabulary>happiness</vocabulary>, every time someone says something to you, all you can do is say, "<reading>Sigh, wha</reading>t (さいわ)?" You sigh and say what. Because you're too happy to really listen. You're just sighing all day and not paying attention.

Sorry, you only learned the kun'yomi reading with 広. So, think of it this way when you need to remember this word's meaning: You're advertising something. It's a big <vocabulary>advertisement</vocabulary> to advertise how terrible a person <reading>こう</reading>いち is. Come up with some terrible things he's done so that you can imagine this crazy Koichi advertisement you made and ran on national TV.

The reading is unlike the kanji reading, so let's use a separate mnemonic to remember this. Just imagine yourself going <vocabulary>to sit</vocabulary> down. You sit down, and the ground collapses below you and you fall. When you land, you find yourself in a nasty, stinking <reading>sewer</reading> (すわ). It is so gross. Taste the sewage in your mouth. Smell it. Feel gross. You shouldn't have sat down on that spot, it was looking awfully dangerous, now that you think about it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

All we need to shoot a <vocabulary>bow</vocabulary> is <reading>you 'n' me</reading> (ゆみ). One person holds the bow, the other fires the arrows. Teamwork makes the dream work. Even for shooting bows. Just you 'n' me.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait, what <reading>was</reading> (わす) the reading? I <vocabulary>forget</vocabulary>... What was it?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
If you know 荷物 and you know 手, then you should be able to Voltron the two together into one mega reading.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.

The readings here are the vocab kun'yomi readings. You have ひ for 日 and や for 焼け (which you learned with the vocab). Combine it with some sunscreen and hopefully you'll prevent the <vocabulary>sunburn</vocabulary>.
The readings come from 書く and 入れる. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.
This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words 書く and 方. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.
The readings come from 書く and 直す. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

When you get sick, your mom calls every day to ask, "Are you better <reading>now</reading> (なお)?" How about NOW!? How about NOW!? Jeez Mom, just let me rest!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have <vocabulary>to wash</vocabulary> <reading>a ro</reading>ck (あら) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Don't confuse this with the same-sounding 戦車 though... unless you're washing your 戦車 in a 洗車...
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
焼き uses the reading you learned with the kanji. 肉 does too. Put them on the grill and enjoy!
The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings. With 焼き, you can use the reading you learned with the kanji. With 鳥 just remember back to the vocab word, とり. Combine and eat.
The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're standing around a <vocabulary>smoke</vocabulary> machine. It's billowing up smoke. Strangely, your buddy Bill Murray is here too. For some reason, he loves the smoke, and he puts his head in it, breathing it in deeply until he goes into a coughing fit. You decide it's time to stop him. "<reading>Kay, Murray</reading> (けむり), it's time to stop that," you say.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 留守 will be important as well.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is the two words 禅 and 寺 put together. The てら gets changed to でら, though.

In terms of when it's pronounced ぜんじ, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a 禅寺 the pronunciation changes to ぜんじ. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as 笑う, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What should be equal above all things? I think each <reading>人</reading> (ひと) should be equal!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

This vocab word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. At least I won't have to bring up the image of you <reading>moon</reading>ing (むね) people with your breasts or whatnot. Oh dang, I just went and did it.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Don't have to use your <vocabulary>brain</vocabulary> for that.
Reading is just what you learned with the kanji. Just use your 脳 a bit and it should be easy.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. 書, however, is kun'yomi in this case and also has rendaku. So just remember that it's read as が for this vocab and you'll be fine.

The reading is kind of weird, sorry. The reading for 葉 is the は you know and love. Then, 書 is かき despite not having a き on the end like you'd expect. So, it's weird. It's shortened like a postcard is a shortened letter, I suppose? Technically it is the 書き reading, but keep in mind that 書き gets rendaku'd.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is the word 読み (like 読む) and the reading you learned for 訓 combined, making <reading>くんよ</reading>み. Sounds familiar? It's that <vocabulary>kun'yomi</vocabulary> reading you've heard so much about.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to allow it. <reading>You're</reading> (ゆる) allowed to do it this one time, okay?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 証明's reading will also be helpful.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This reading for this is a bit of an exception. You know the reading for 達 is たつ, but here it's shortened, to just たっ. So make sure you remember.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This uses the kun'yomi reading which you learned with 遠い. How convenient!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 曜日 as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same as 閉める.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  

Ever heard of the "<reading>Kaw Kaw</reading> (かか) Crow Gang"? They are bad news, always eating from garbage and squawking "kaw kaw" ... You don't want <vocabulary>to be involved</vocabulary> with them.
The reading is the vocab 関西's reading and the kanji reading of 弁, combined.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to be <vocabulary>quiet</vocabulary>. <reading>She's</reading> (しず) being nice and quiet, unlike you!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word is made up of a single kanji, and it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi readings for the second two. You haven't learned this reading for 工 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You want your <vocabulary>sugar sculptures</vocabulary> to be made into <reading>coo</reading>kies (く)! Cookies are your other favorite snack, so having a cookie that's really just entirely made of sugar is the absolute best.

Also, watch out for the rendaku on 細, it's easy to miss if you're focusing on remembering this new on'yomi reading.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
